awd_titl_txt: International Workshop on Quasi-Isometries and Groups: Rigidity and Classification
awd_abstract_narration:
This project supports participation of US based mathematicians in the workshop "Quasi-isometries and  groups: rigidity and classification" which will take place from September 9th until September 14th, 2019, in Ventotene, Italy. A major goal of the workshop is to train and support the next generation of mathematicians in the field of coarse geometry and quasi-isometries. The conference will help to educate graduate students and recent PhDs on the latest developments in the field. The conference will introduce junior mathematicians to various topics in geometric group theory and bring them up to the forefront of research. A part of the conference will be devoted to three mini-courses, taught by experts known also for their ability to give enlightening lectures. In parallel to the minicourses, there will be research talks. The speakers will be prompted by the organizers to aim their lectures at a broad audience of mathematicians. The majority of funding will support junior participants coming from USA. The organizing committee will encourage and support broad and diverse participation. In particular, women mathematicians and members of other under-represented groups are especially encouraged to apply for support. 

The workshop consists of the following three minicourses on different aspects of "Quasi-isometric rigidity for certain classes of solvable groups"  (Tullia Dymarz, University of Wisconsin), "The asymptotic geometry of certain Artin groups"(Jingyin Huang, Ohio State University), and "Analysis on boundaries of hyperbolic groups" (John MacKay, University of Bristol). The workshop will also feature research talks and informal discussions. Participants will include leading U.S. and European researchers from different areas relevant to the centerpiece of the workshop (3-manifold topology, geometric group theory and hyperbolic geometry) as well as junior researchers, both graduate students and postdocs. Additional information can be found at the workshop website https://www.ventoteneinternationalworkshops.net/

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This grant supported the fourth and fifth meetings of the International Ventotene Conference.

2019: Ventotene IV, Quasi-isometries and groups: rigidity and classification. The fourth meeting took place September 9-14, 2019 on the subject of Quasi-isometries and was or ganized by Martin Bridgeman (Boston College), Anna Erschler (ENS Paris), Stefano Francaviglia (Universita di Bologna), Roberto Frigerio (Universita di Pisa), Fanny Kassel (IHES and CNRS), Alessandra Iozzi (ETHZ), and Michah Sageev (Technion). The workshop was co-sponsored by the National Science Foundation, the Zurich Graduate School of Mathematics, Anna Erschler European Research Council GrolsRan grant, Fanny Kassel?s European Research Council DiGGeS grant, the GNSAGA from the Istituto Nazionale di Alta Matematica, the Department of Mathematics of the Universit`a di Bologna, the Swiss Mathematical Society, the FNR of Jean-Marc Schlenker and the Universite de Luxembourg, the project Jeune Geometres of the Fondation Louis D., Bruno Martelli research funds and the Stiftung zur Forderung der mathematischen Wissenschaften in der Schweiz.

The workshop was well attended with 84 participants (34 with permanent or tenure track positions, 21 postdocs and 29 students, 24 women), all of them funded. Of the 84 participants, 14 were from the US.

There were three minicourses: Quasi-isometric rigidity for certain classes of solvable groups (Tullia Dymarz, University of Wisconsin), The asymptotic geometry of certain Artin groups (Jingyin Huang, Ohio State University), Analysis on boundaries of hyperbolic groups (John MacKay, Uni- versity of Bristol)

There was also a lightning talks session to which 26 students and postdocs presenting.

In addition there were 12 lectures by Christopher Cashen (Universit ̈at Wien), David Hume (University of Oxford), Xiangdong Xie (Bowling Green State University), Jeremie Brieussel (Universite de Montpellier), Ruth Charney (Brandeis University), Francois Dahmani (Universite de Grenoble Alpes), Peter Haissinsky (Universite de Aix-Marseille), Ursula Hamenstadt (Universitat Bonn), Enrico Le Donne (Universita di Pisa) and Jyvaskylan Yliopisto), Gabriele Link (Karlsruhe Institut fur Technologie) Sara Maloni (University of Virginia) Katie Vokes (Institut des Hautes E ́tudes Scientifiques).

2021: Ventotene V, Counting Problems: The fifth meeting took place September 6-11, 2019 on the subject of Counting Problems and was organized by Martin Bridgeman (Boston College), Stefano Francaviglia (Universit`a di Bologna), Roberto Frigerio (Universita di Pisa), Alessandra Iozzi (ETHZ), and Michah Sageev (Technion). The workshop was co-sponsored by the National Science Foundation, the Zurich Graduate School of Mathematics, Alessandra Iozzi ETHZ research grant, the GNSAGA from the Istituto Nazionale di Alta Matematica, the Compositio Foundation, the Department of Mathematics of the Universita di Bologna, Forschungsinstitut fur Mathematik, ETH Zurich, Switzerland, Ministry for Education, University and Research PRIN project 2017JZ2SW5, Italy, and the Stiftung zur Forderung der mathematischen Wissenschaften in der Schweiz.

The workshop was well attended with 95 participants (28 with permanent or tenure track positions, 31 postdocs and 36 students, 25 women), all of them funded. Due to the pandemic, of the 95 participants, only 6 were from the US.

There were three minicourses: On counting, with number theoretic flavours (Claire Burrin, ETHZ), Ergodic theorems, multiple mixing, and arithmetic counting problems (Alex Gorodnik, Universitat Zurich), Flat and hyperbolic enumerative geometry (Anton Zorich, Universit ́e Pierre et Marie Curie-Universite Paris Diderot) .

There was also a lightning talk session in which 23 students and postdocs presented.

In addition there were 9 lectures by Manfred Einsiedler (ETHZ), Min Lee (University of Bristol), Martin M ̈oller (Goethe Universitat-Frankfurt), Ga ̈etan Borot (Humboldt Universit ̈at zu Berlin), Aaron Calderon (Yale University), Samantha Fairchild (Max Planck Institut, Leipzig), Giovanni Italiano (Scuola Normale Superiore di Pisa), Bram Petri (Sorbonne Universite), Gabriela Weitze- Schmithusen (Universitat des Saarlandes).
